title: Billionaire Jim Ratcliffe snaps up North Sea oil fields

Sun, Oct 11, 2015, 21:32 BST - UK Markets closed Billionaire Jim Ratcliffe snaps up North Sea oil fields By Mehreen Khan | Telegraph – 57 minutes ago 24.00 +2.18 
Ineos will purchase North Sea oil and gas fields after Russian billionaire Mikhail Fridman was told to sell up 
Billionaire Jim Ratcliffe has agreed a deal to buy North Sea oil and gas fields which provide energy to heat 1 in 10 British homes. 
Ineos, the chemical company owned by Mr Ratcliffe, confirmed on Sunday that it had struck a deal to purchase all the British gas fields owned by from Germany company DEA Group. 
The move comes after DEA (Shenzhen: 002260.SZ - news ) 's owner, Russian billionaire Mikhail Fridman, was told by the British government he had to sell the fields or see his company, LetterOne, have its oil licence revoked. 
The clampdown on Mr Fridman comes after the Western government have tightened their sanctions regime on Moscow over the conflict in Ukraine. 
• Russian billionaire mulls sale of North Sea gasfields 
The fields, the largest of which are Breagh and Clipper South, are Ineos's first acquisition in the North Sea. 
Together, they provide as much as 8pc of all gas in the UK. Ineos described the fields as a "high quality, low risk assets" which are are well-positioned near its existing fields in the North East of England and Scotland. 
Mr Ratcliffe, chairman of Ineos said: “We are pleased to acquire a strong portfolio of natural gas assets and bring on board a highly successful and experienced North Sea industry team." 
The company, which runs the Grangemouth refinery in Scotland, announced in March it had invested £168m in UK shale gas exploration through a deal with IGas Energy (LSE: IGAS.L - news ) . It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) will see the two companies drill up to 11 wells in the North West and frack six of them 
"Ineos has been very open about its intention to make strategic investments in the North Sea and this acquisition is our first step in fulfilling this goal. It will also help our UK petrochemical assets to have ongoing access to competitive energy”, said Mr Ratcliffe.
